pageTitle: There's a Thanksgiving Race Near You | Runner's World
TableContextTimeStampAfterTable: {39056=Thanksgiving Surpasses July 4 as No. 1 Day for Road Racing, 35846=There will be some fast running preceding the feasting on Thursday. New England’s most venerable Thanksgiving Day race, the 4.748-mile Manchester Road Race, is expected to have 15,000 competitors for its 77th running, including 2012’s top three male finishers, Aaron Braun, Haron Lagat, and Donn Cabral. A year ago, Braun tied Phillimon Hanneck’s 1995 course record of 21:19, and he’s coming off the 12K national title a week and a half ago. Lagat won in Manchester in 2009. Cabral, a 2012 steeplechase Olympian, is Manchester’s local hero; he’s from the nearby town of Glastonbury., 30297=If you value lasting power more than size, then you'd probably enjoy running the YMCA Turkey Trot 8K in Buffalo, New York, which has been run every year since 1896, and is therefore the oldest continuously run road race in the United States. Berwick, Pennsylvania’s Run for the Diamonds, a 9-miler that should draw about 2,000 runners, is also one of the oldest races in the country. It was first run in 1908, and has been every year since except 1918 and 1919., 37459=Olympic 10,000-meter silver medalist Sally Kipyego of Kenya heads a women’s roster that includes 2013 NCAA 10,000-meter champion Betsy Saina, American Olympic steeplechaser Bridget Franek, and 2013 USA indoor 3000-meter champion Chelsea Reilly. Lukas Verzbicas will be at the Oceanside Turkey Trot, a 5-miler along the California coast. Verzbicas’ recovery from a devastating cycling accident in 2012 is every bit as remarkable as the prowess that made him the fifth U.S. high school runner to break 4:00 for the mile and, later on, a world junior champion in the triathlon.   “I will be running for the win,” Verzbicas told the Oceanside-Camp Pendleton Patch. “I am still coming back from my spinal cord injury last year and am in a heavy training block right now. I am very excited to run alongside 10,000 of my fellow Southern Californians.” Verzbicas lives in Chula Vista and works out at the nearby U. S. Olympic Training Center. On Thursday, there will probably be a race near where you live or might be visiting. Use our race finder to locate your closest opportunity to join the fun., 5159=Copyright © 2015 Rodale Inc. No reproduction, transmission or display is permitted without the written permissions of Rodale Inc., 36852=From the  elite perspective, Thursday’s other significant race is the Silicon Valley Turkey Trot in San Jose, California. As Race Results Weekly reports, the men’s field features the 2012 runner-up Leonard Korir, a Kenyan who competed for Iona college, plus American mile record holder Alan Webb, three-time national road mile champion David Torrence, Mexican 5000-meter Olympian Diego Estrada, and .US Championships 12K runner-up Shadrack Biwott., 28423=As we reported earlier this month, Thanksgiving Day now far surpasses the Fourth of July as the most popular holiday for road racing in the United States, with 676.000 competitors having raced on Thanksgiving in 2011. Running USA, a nonprofit organization that keeps tabs on road racing trends, knows of 470 turkey trots in the United States on Thursday. The races run the gamut, from huge, multi-distance events and races with elite fields to small-town celebrations and some of the oldest road races in the country. Last year, the five largest Thanksgiving races were:, 36461=Manchester’s women’s field features 2012 Olympic marathoner Desiree Davila, who is now on the Hansons team roster under her married name Desiree Linden, and the race’s 2012 women’s runner-up, Lisa Uhl. Runner’s World’s Amby Burfoot, the 1968 Boston Marathon champ, will be doing this race for the 51st year in a row. He won it nine times between 1968 and 1977.}
textBeforeTable: As we reported earlier this month, Thanksgiving Day now far surpasses the Fourth of July as the most popular holiday for road racing in the United States, with 676.000 competitors having raced on Thanksgiving in 2011. Running USA, a nonprofit organization that keeps tabs on road racing trends, knows of 470 turkey trots in the United States on Thursday. The races run the gamut, from huge, multi-distance events and races with elite fields to small-town celebrations and some of the oldest road races in the country. Last year, the five largest Thanksgiving races were: Canadian Customers Your Privacy Rights
textAfterTable: If you value lasting power more than size, then you'd probably enjoy running the YMCA Turkey Trot 8K in Buffalo, New York, which has been run every year since 1896, and is therefore the oldest continuously run road race in the United States. Berwick, Pennsylvania’s Run for the Diamonds, a 9-miler that should draw about 2,000 runners, is also one of the oldest races in the country. It was first run in 1908, and has been every year since except 1918 and 1919. Advertisement Subscribe To Our Newsletters Training and Nutrition Sent every Tuesday (training) and Thursday (nutrition).
